{{Infobox accounting body |abbreviation = CMA Canada |name_in_local_language= |image = |image_border = |image_caption = |motto = |predecessor = |formation = {{Start date and years ago|1920|05|03}} |legal_status = Continued under the ''Canada Not-for-profit Corporations Act''<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=598593&V_TOKEN=1496775411178&crpNm=Society%20of%20Management%20Accountants&crpNmbr=&bsNmbr=|title= Federal Corporation Information - 059859-3: The Society of Management Accountants of Canada|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= ic.gc.ca|publisher= |access-date= June 6, 2017}}</ref> |objective = Encourage professionalism in accountancy in Canada |headquarters = [[Toronto, Ontario]], {{flag|Canada}} |coords = |region_served = |membership_num = |students_num = |members_designations = CPA, CMA, or FCPA, FCMA |language = English, French |website = |remarks = }}
'''The Society of Management Accountants of Canada''' ({{lang-fr|La Société des comptables en management du Canada}}), also known as '''Certified Management Accountants of Canada''' ({{lang-fr|Comptables en management accrédités du Canada}}) and '''CMA Canada''', awards the [[Certified Management Accountant]] designation in [[Canada]].
==Activities== Until September 2015,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/become-a-cpa/pathways-to-becoming-a-cpa/unification-information-for-legacy-studentscandidates/cpa-certification-program-cma-legacy-student-transition|title= Guidelines for transitioning CMA students|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= cpacanada.ca|publisher= |access-date= June 6, 2017}}</ref> CMA Canada, through its provincial and territorial affiliates, granted the CMA professional designation in accounting and was responsible for standards-setting, accreditation and the continuing professional development of CMAs.
CMAs applied expertise in accounting, management and strategy to ensure corporate accountability and help organizations maintain a long-term competitive advantage. In that regard, CMA Canada offered executive development programs, online courses, and knowledge management publications.<ref>{{Cite web |title = Professional Development |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=4602&la_id=1 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141010195112/http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=4602&la_id=1 |archive-date = October 10, 2014 |dead-url = yes |accessdate = June 6, 2017 |df = }}</ref>
Management Accounting Guidelines<ref>{{Cite web|title= Management Accounting Guidelines (MAGs)|url= http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=4614&la_id=1|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20141017182018/http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=4614&la_id=1|archive-date= October 17, 2014|dead-url= yes|accessdate= June 6, 2017|df= }}</ref> and Management Accounting Practices<ref>{{Cite web|title= Management Accounting Practices (MAPs)|url= http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=4616&la_id=1|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120425073034/http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=4616&la_id=1|archive-date= April 25, 2012|dead-url= yes|accessdate= June 6, 2017|df= }}</ref> were published by CMA Canada to specify the best practice on key topics in management accounting. They were available for download free of charge or on CD for a nominal charge to CMAs, and could be purchased by non-members.<ref>{{Cite web |title = Business Resources |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=1885&la_id=1 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141008034415/http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm?ci_id=1885&la_id=1 |archive-date = October 8, 2014 |dead-url = yes |accessdate = 2011-11-14 |df = }}</ref> CPA Canada has taken over the programme, and has issued update guidance for many such matters under its own name,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/business-and-accounting-resources/management-accounting|title= Management accounting|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= cpacanada.ca|publisher= |access-date= June 6, 2017}}</ref> although none of the documents appear to acknowledge their SMAC origins.
From 1953 to 2015, the Society operated a foundation that was dedicated to furthering research in the field of management accounting.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Federal Corporation Information - 042154-5: The Research Foundation of the Society of Management Accountants of Canada|url = https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=421545&V_TOKEN=1496775411178&crpNm=Society%20of%20Management%20Accountants&crpNmbr=&bsNmbr=|website=ic.gc.ca|accessdate = June 6, 2017}}</ref>
==History of the Society==
The mission of the Society has closely tracked the evolution from [[cost accounting]] to [[management accounting]] in Canada, and its distinction from [[financial accounting]]:<ref>{{Cite web|title = ''Professional dominance: The relationship between financial accounting and management accounting, 1926-1986'' |url = http://www.allbusiness.com/accounting-reporting/managerial-accounting/404769-1.html |author = Alan J.Richardson |publisher = Accounting Historians Journal |date = 2002-12-01|accessdate = 2011-11-08}}</ref>
* 1920 - Incorporation of '''The Canadian Society of Cost Accountants''', with head office in [[Hamilton, Ontario]] * 1926 - Introduction of ''Cost and Management'', the predecessor of ''CMA Magazine'' * 1930 - Name changed to '''The Canadian Society of Cost Accountants and Industrial Engineers''' * 1941 - Formation of provincial societies in Ontario and Quebec, with the power to grant the newly established professional designation of '''Registered Industrial Accountant''' ("RIA") * 1948 - Name changed to '''Society of Industrial and Cost Accountants of Canada''' * 1968 - Name changed to '''The Society of Industrial Accountants of Canada''' * 1977 - Name changed to '''The Society of Management Accountants of Canada''' * 1985 - Introduction of the professional designation of '''Certified Management Accountant''' ("CMA"), with existing RIAs being [[Grandfather clause|grandfathered in]] * 2004 - '''CMA''' is registered as a trademark by CMA Canada * 2006 - '''Certified Management Accountant''' is registered as a trademark by CMA Canada * 2007 - Incorporation of the CMA Canada Research Foundation * 2009 - Introduction of ''The National Standard for Public Accounting for Certified Management Accountants'' to govern the affairs of CMAs that have entered into public practice<ref>{{Cite web|title = ''The National Standard for Public Accounting for Certified Management Accountants'' |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm/ci_id/2550/la_id/1/document/1/re_id/0 |date = 2009-09-12 |accessdate = 2011-11-08}}</ref> * 2014 - Unification of the profession within CPA Canada, with legislative implementation substantially complete as of May 2017.
===Timeline=== {{Horizontal timeline |title=Timeline of Certified Management Accountants of Canada |title-colour= |caption= |margin= |collapsible=no |Row1={{note row |from=1900 |to=2025 |1-at=1900 |1-text= |1-shift= |1-lift= |1-arrow=none |2-at=1920 |2-text=formation of CSCA<ref group=a>Canadian Society of Cost Accountants</ref>{{efn|Originally created by the Dominion Association of Chartered Accountants, with membership originally restricted to chartered accountants,<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= The Canadian Society of Cost Accountants|url= https://archive.org/stream/canadianchartere10canauoft#page/30/mode/2up|journal= The Canadian Chartered Accountant|location= Toronto|publisher= Dominion Association of Chartered Accountants|date= July 1920|volume = X|issue = 1|pages = 31{{en dash}}34|accessdate= June 24, 2014}}</ref> in a move designed to prevent the General Accountants Association from moving into the growing field of [[cost accounting]].{{sfn|Richardson|2000|p=110}}}} |2-shift= |2-lift= |2-arrow= |3-at=2012 |3-text=creation of CPA in Quebec |3-shift= |3-lift= |3-arrow= }} |Row4={{note row |from=1900 |to=2025 |1-at=1900 |1-text= |1-shift= |1-lift= |1-arrow=none |3-at=1939 |3-text=CSCA split{{efn|those members wishing to concentrate more on [[management accounting]] left to form the Controllers' Institute of Canada (later part of the [[Financial Executives International|Financial Executives Institute]]){{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=90}}}} |3-shift= |3-lift= |3-arrow= |5-at=2013 |5-text=formation of CPA Canada |5-shift= |5-lift= |5-arrow= }} |Row5={{note row |from=1900 |to=2025 |1-at=1900 |1-text= |1-shift= |1-lift= |1-arrow= |2-at=1926 |2-text=Introduction of ''Cost and Management'' |2-shift= |2-lift= |2-arrow= |3-at=1985 |3-text=RIA designation superseded by CMA |3-shift= |3-lift= |3-arrow= |4-at=2014 |4-text=Unification complete |4-shift= |4-lift= |4-arrow= }} |Row10={{timeline row |colour = |border = |border-top = |border-bottom = |from=1900 |to=2025 |1-text = |1-to = 1927 |1-colour= |2-text = Certificate of efficiency<ref>{{cite book |author= J. Nelson Allan|year= 1982|title= History of the Society of Management Accountants of Canada|url= |location= Hamilton|publisher= Society of Management Accountants of Canada|page= 21|isbn= 0-920212-45-X }}</ref>{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=90}} |2-to = 1941 |2-colour=lightyellow |3-text = Registered Industrial Accountant{{efn|The designation was created once provincial societies began to be formed.{{sfn|Richardson|2000|p=112}} Originally known as "Registered Industrial and Cost Accountant" or "RIA" in Ontario<ref>{{Cite canlaw|short title = The Society of Industrial and Cost Accountants of Ontario Act, 1941|abbr = S.O.|year = 1941|chapter = 77|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1941onta#page/316/mode/2up}}</ref> and "Licentiate of the Cost and Management Institute" or "LCMI" in Quebec,<ref>{{Cite canlaw|short title = Loi constituant en corporation l'Institut de gestion industrielle et commerciale|abbr = S.Q.|year = 1941|chapter = 95|link = https://www.bibliotheque.assnat.qc.ca/DepotNumerique_v2/AffichageFichier.aspx?idf=119244}}{{fr icon}}</ref> it was simplified in some, but not all, provinces around 1967.<ref>{{Cite canlaw|short title = The Society of Industrial Accountants of Ontario Act, 1967|abbr = S.O.|year = 1967|chapter = 129|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1967onta#page/548/mode/2up}}</ref>}} |3-to = 1985 |3-colour=#ccffff |4-text = [[Certified Management Accountant]] |4-to = 2022 |4-colour=#ffccff }} |Row11={{timeline row |colour = |border = |border-top = |border-bottom = |from=1900 |to=2025 |1-text = |1-to = 2012 |1-colour= |2-text = CPA |2-to = 2025 |2-colour=#E5E4E2 }} |Row12={{Scale row |from=1900 |to=2025 |increment=25 }} }} {{reflist|group=a}}
==Competencies, accreditation process and post-qualification development==
CMAs are expected to undergo specific training and practical experience to achieve specified competencies in the area of strategic management accounting, which are intended to prepare them for senior leadership roles in their organizations.<ref name="CompMap">{{Cite web|title = ''The CMA Competency Map'' |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm/ci_id/19412/la_id/1/document/1/re_id/0 |accessdate = 2011-11-09}}</ref> There are six functional competencies and four enabling competencies in that regard:
'''Functional competencies'''
* [[Strategic management]] * [[Risk management]] and [[corporate governance|governance]] * [[Performance management]] * [[Performance measurement]] * [[Finance|Financial management]] * [[Financial reporting]]
'''Enabling competencies'''
* [[Problem solving]] and [[decision making]] * [[Leadership]] and [[group dynamics]] * [[Professionalism]] and [[ethics|ethical behaviour]] * [[Communication]]
While candidates may come from a variety of backgrounds, the CMA career path is expected to progress in the following manner:<ref name="CompMap"/>
{| border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" |- | '''Stage''' || '''Phase''' || '''Nature''' |- | '''Acquisition''' | Prior to passage of CMA Entrance Examination | In process of completing undergraduate studies, or 5–7 years thereafter. Already in junior to [[middle management]] level in their organization. |- | '''Basic Proficiency''' | Acquisition of the CMA designation and the following five years thereafter | Already in [[middle management]] level, and progressively gaining more practical experience and responsibility. |- | '''Advanced Proficiency''' | 5–10 years post-qualification | Early- to mid-career professionals, with most having achieved more senior positions within the [[middle management]] layer. A significant number hold introductory [[senior management]] positions in their area of specialization or in the organization as a whole. |- | '''Mastery''' | 10–25 years post-qualification | Late-career professionals, operating in [[senior management]] roles. Most are either the highest-ranking financial officers in their organization or financial professionals with specialized knowledge in particular functional areas. A significant proportion of individuals are operating in the desired "C" space - i.e., [[Chief executive officer|CEO]], [[Chief financial officer|CFO]], [[Chief risk officer|CRO]] or [[Chief information officer|CIO]] - and some of these are leaders of large enterprises or significant [[strategic business unit]]s. |}
CMA candidates (without advanced professional standing) must have obtained a university degree and have credits in a specified list of subjects, before they can write the CMA Entrance Examination.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ''CMA Entrance Examination'' |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm/ci_id/4122/la_id/1/document/1/re_id/0 |accessdate = 2011-11-09}}</ref> Upon passing this stage, they then enter the Strategic Leadership Programme ("SLP"),<ref>{{Cite web|title = ''CMA Canada Strategic Leadership Program'' |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm/ci_id/4123/la_id/1/document/1/re_id/0 |accessdate = 2011-11-09}}</ref> which has the following components:<ref>{{Cite web|title = ''The CMA Canada Accreditation Process'' |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm/ci_id/4121/la_id/1/document/1/re_id/0 |accessdate = 2011-11-09}}</ref>
* ''Development Phase'' ** followed by the successful passing of the '''CMA Case Examination''' * ''Application Phase'' ** leading to the successful preparation and presentation of the '''Board Report''', containing detailed analysis and recommendations on a specified case study * Completion of 24 months of '''relevant full-time progressive practical experience confirmed by the employer''' - of which at least 12 months must be concurrent with the SLP ** Candidates are expected to be '''expanding their on-the-job responsibilities while undertaking the SLP'''
Successful passage of the above will result in the granting of the CMA designation. After attaining the designation, there are specified requirements for continuous professional learning and development that must be undertaken to remain in good standing.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ''The National Standard for Continuous Professional Learning and Development for certified Management Accountants'' |url = http://www.cma-canada.org/index.cfm/ci_id/5104/la_id/1/document/1/re_id/0 |accessdate = 2011-11-09}}</ref>
==Notable members== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Navdeep Bains]] * [[Peter G. Christie]] * [[Roy Megarry]] * [[Frederick John Mitchell]] * [[Harinder Takhar]] * [[J. Grant Thiessen]] * [[Rick Thorpe]] {{div col end}}

Richardson|year= 2000|title= Building the Canadian Chartered Accountancy Profession: A Biography of George Edwards, FCA, CBE, LLD, 1861-1947 |url= http://umiss.lib.olemiss.edu:82/record=b1029993|journal= Accounting Historians Journal|publisher= [[Academy of Accounting Historians]]|volume= 27|issue= 2|pages= 87{{en dash}}116|ref= {{harvid|Richardson|2000}}}}

'''Charles Couch James''' (November 21, 1882 – September 30, 1957)<ref>''The Sons of the American Revolution Magazine,'' Volumes 49-53. 1954-58. p. 30</ref><ref name="ASME 1958">ASME, ''Mechanical Engineering,'' Volume 80. 1958. p. 48</ref> was an American factory accountant in his early career and later [[accountant|consulting accountant]] at Stevenson, Jordan & Harrison, New York,<ref>''N.A.C.A. Bulletin,'' Volume 14. 1932. p. 181</ref> known as 9th president of the [[Society for Advancement of Management]] in the year 1948-1949.<ref>Institution of Works Managers, [[Arthur Primrose Young]]. ''American management techniques and practices and their bearing on productivity in British industry: a survey.'' 1948. p. 41</ref><ref name="SAM 1988">''S.A.M. Advanced Management Journal,'' Volume 53, 1988. p. 40</ref>
== Biography == === Youth, education and early career=== James was born in [[Lincoln, Illinois]] in 1882,<ref name="Poor 1957">''Poor's Register of Directors and Executives, United States and Canada,'' 1957. p. 2401</ref> and started his working career after his high school graduation at the turn of the century.<ref name="ASME 1958"/> After a few years he became Assistant Superintendent of Construction at the [[St. Louis–San Francisco Railway]] on the line between St. Louis and Memphis. Here he received his first practical experience in the accounting and the operating of departments.<ref name = "NAA 1930">National Association of Accountants. ''Proceedings of the International Cost Conference.'' 1930. p. 102</ref>
In 1909 James was appointed at the [[Interstate Commerce Commission]] at the staff of examiners of railroad accounts. In the next two decades he served a several large organizations, such as [[Southern Pacific Railroad]], the [[Merchant Shipbuilding Corporation]], [[Merritt-Chapman & Scott]], Cramp-Morris Industrials, Inc., later part of [[Baldwin Locomotive Works]], and the [[Westinghouse Electric Corporation]].<ref name = "NAA 1930"/>
=== Further career and other work === In 1931 James became associate at Counsellor, Stevenson, Jordan & Harrison, Inc., where by 1945 he was Associate Counsellor.<ref name="NAA 1945">National Association of Accountants. ''Proceedings of the International Cost Conference.'' 1945. p. 26</ref><ref>Society for Advancement of Management. ''Proceedings [of the Annual Conference].'' 1951. p. 214</ref> He was a specialist in [[cost accounting]] and factory management.<ref>''The Gazette and Daily from York,'' Pennsylvania. February 15, 1947. p. 6</ref>
Beside his consulting work James had been visiting lecturer at [[Columbia University]] and other New York Universities and at [[Pennsylvania State College]]. He was a delegate for the ASME to the Eighth International Management Congress at Stockholm.<ref name="ASME 1958"/>
James had been a longstanding member of the [[National Association of Accountants]], present at annual conventions, active on chapter meetings, and contributor to the N.A.C.A. Bulletin. He served as President of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Accountants in 1945-46,<ref name="NAA 1945"/><ref>National Association of Accountants, ''Proceedings of the International Cost Conference,'' 1945. p. 26</ref> In 1948 James had also joined the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]] (ASME).<ref>American Society of Mechanical Engineers, ''ASME Membership List,'' 1953. p. 165</ref> In 1948-49 he served as national president of the [[Society for Advancement of Management]] (SAM) as successor of [[William L. McGrath]], and was succeeded by [[Dillard E. Bird]].<ref name="SAM 1988"/>
=== Personal === James was married Mrs. Blanche M. James, and they had two sons, Leonard G. and Norman James, and a daughter, Louise M. James.<ref name="ASME 1958"/>
== Selected publications == * James, Charles C. "Depreciation and the Value of Public Utilities." ''The Journal of Accountancy'' (1916): 409-416. * Charles C. James, "The Basis of the Flexible and the Variable Budget in an Expanding Economy," in: ''Advanced Management,'' Vol. XVII, No. 9, September 1952.

revision.text:
'''Constantin Belimace''' (July 1848–1932) was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]]-born [[Romania]]n and [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] poet.
He was born into an [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] family in [[Malovišta]], a village that formed part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]'s [[Rumelia Eyalet]] and is now in the Republic of Macedonia. His father was Tașcu Belimace. He attended school in his native village and at a Serbian school in Belgrade. In 1873, he moved to [[Bucharest]], capital of the [[Romanian Old Kingdom]]. There, he opened a restaurant favored by students, particularly from south of the Danube, and by writers. In the enthusiastically patriotic atmosphere that followed the [[Romanian War of Independence]], Belimace began composing poems, thus becoming among the first writers in the [[Aromanian language]]: "Cucotul" ([[Romanian language|Romanian]]: "Cocoșul"; "The Rooster") and "Dimândarea părintească" ("Porunca părintească"; "The Parents' Command"). These appeared, respectively, in ''România'' and ''Voința națională''. Later, together with others, they were published in Andrei Bagav's 1887 ''Cartea de alegere'' (''Cartea de citire''; ''Reader'').<ref name="sasu"/>
Belimace helped found the Macedo-Romanian cultural society and Lumina association, and took part in editing periodicals such as ''Frațil’ea într’u dreptate'' and ''Macedonia''. His contributions appeared in ''Frațil’ea'', ''Grai bun'', ''Lumina'', ''Peninsula Balcanică'' and ''Românul de la Pind'', as well as in various calendars and almanacs. After returning to Macedonia, he worked as a supervisor at the Romanian boarding high school in [[Bitola]]. During World War I, he was held hostage in Bulgaria for two years. He died in Bitola in 1932, when the city was in the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]].<ref name="sasu">Aurel Sasu (ed.), ''Dicționarul biografic al literaturii române'', vol. I, p. 152. Pitești: Editura Paralela 45, 2004. {{ISBN|973-697-758-7}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act''' is a Canadian regulatory statute, which has seen many amendments since it was originally passed in 1970.<ref name=cpla>[http://www.laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-38/FullText.html laws.justice.gc.ca: "Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. C-38)"]</ref> It governs the packaging, labelling, sale, importation and advertising of prepackaged and certain other products.<ref name=cpla/>
It requires that prepackaged consumer products bear accurate and meaningful labelling information to help consumers make informed purchasing decisions.<ref name=cb/> The Act prohibits the making of false or misleading representations and sets out specifications for mandatory label information such as the product's name, net quantity and dealer identity.<ref name=cb/> It allows designated inspectors to: enter any place at any reasonable time; examine prepackaged products, open packages, examine and make copies of documents or papers; and seize products, labelling, packaging or advertising material which do not conform with the Act and Regulations. Conviction of an offense under the Act is rewarded with up to a year in prison and a $10,000 fine.<ref name=cb>[http://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/02907.html competitionbureau.gc.ca: "Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act"], 2018-02-22</ref>
The administration and enforcement of the Act and Regulations, as they relate to non‑food products, is the responsibility of the Competition Bureau, an agency of [[Industry Canada]].<ref name=site/> Administration and enforcement of the Act and Regulations, as it relates to food products, is the responsibility of the [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] (CFIA).<ref name=site/> There are certain classes of items that are exempt from the CPLA, such as commercial, industrial, or institutional use only products or drugs or products for export only.<ref name=site>[http://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/01248.html competitionbureau.gc.ca: "Guide to the Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act and Regulations"], October 1999</ref> The regulations govern the consistency, completeness, and accuracy of the labelling and packaging of consumer goods.<ref name=faq/> These regulations create a uniform method for the labelling and packaging of consumer goods to assist consumers in making informed choices in the marketplace.<ref name=faq>[http://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/acts-and-regulations/faq-consumer-packaging-and-labelling-regulations/eng/1426692873531/1426692889910 "Frequently Asked Questions: Consumer Packaging and Labelling Regulations"], 2015-03-18</ref> A helpful Guide is available from the Federal government.<ref>[http://www.publications.gc.ca/site/eng/96421/publication.html publications.gc.ca: "Guide to the Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act and regulations"] (1999)</ref> The CPLA broadly defines "product" to mean any article that is, or may be, the subject of trade or commerce, including both food and non-food items.<ref>[http://www.doingbusinessincanada.com/legal-guide-0/federal-consumer-product--and-labelling-standards-1/consumer-packaging-and-labelling-act-217 "Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act"]</ref> Textiles fall under the [[Textile Labelling Act]], while precious metals fall under the [[Precious Metals Marking Act]].<ref>[https://www.canada.ca/en/services/business/permits/federallyregulatedbusinessactivities/labellingrequirements.html canada.ca: "Labelling requirements"], 2017-05-12</ref>
==History==
The Act has undergone several major revisions throughout its time: in 2002-12-31, in 2011-11-29, in 2015-02-26.<ref>[http://www.laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-38/PITIndex.html laws.justice.gc.ca: "Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. C-38) - Full Documents available for previous versions"]</ref>
In 2016, Two executives of Mucci International Marketing Inc. and Mucci Pac Ltd. and their companies were levied fines by the [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency|CFIA]] tribunal that totalled $1.5 million. Their offense was fraudulently to put "Product of Canada" labels on large quantities of peppers, [[tomatoes]] and [[cucumbers]] grown mainly in [[Mexico]]. The defendants supplied the mislabelled produce to [[Costco]], to [[Loblaws]] and to [[Sobeys]]. The fraud at the [[Ontario Food Terminal]] was discovered in 2012, and investigators later executed in 2013 and 2014 three [[search warrants]], which resulted in the seizure of more than 70 boxes of documents. A court in [[Windsor, Ontario]] heard the case. The agreed statement of facts quoted an email of a Mucci worker, that he was told "to make it Canada even though it is Mexico."<ref>[http://business.financialpost.com/commodities/agriculture/it-says-product-of-canada-but-is-it-the-growing-problem-of-ferreting-out-counterfeit-vegetables financialpost.com: ``It says 'Product of Canada' but is it? The growing problem of ferreting out counterfeit vegetables''], 29 May 2017</ref> The company, which was at the time located in [[Kingsville, Ontario]], was also sentenced to [[probation]] for a three-year term.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/windsor/kingsville-company-fined-1-5m-for-misrepresenting-products-country-of-origin-1.3621671 cbc.ca: "Kingsville company fined $1.5M for misrepresenting products' country of origin"], 8 Jun 2016</ref>
In November 2017, a [[Maidstone, Ontario]] tomato processing company, that in addition had received a controversial $3-million provincial grant, was convicted of fraudulently mislabelling products as [[Organic food|organic]] under the CAPA as well as other legislation. The owner and the company were also charged with falsifying the country of origin on their products between September 2013 and July 2015, passing off with labels that read "Product of Canada" produce that was American in origin. The owner was charged with lying to a federal food inspector on 8 January 2015. The case was heard in the [[Ontario Court of Justice]]. Separately, the company went bankrupt, owing more than a hundred creditors a total of over $25 million.<ref>[http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/thomas-canning-to-plead-guilty-to-mislabelling-products-as-organic windsorstar.ca: "Thomas Canning to plead guilty to mislabelling products as organic"], 12 Oct 2017</ref><ref name=pcom>[https://www.producer.com/2017/03/ont-company-faces-legal-action-on-several-fronts/ producer.com: "Ont. company faces legal action on several fronts"], 9 Mar 2017</ref>
On 12 March 2018, a [[Leamington, Ontario]] greenhouse grower named AMCO Produce and its directors Fausto Amicone and Mark Wehby answered to charges brought by the CFIA for origin-of-vegetable fraud in a Windsor court. The corporation pleaded guilty to three charges under the [[Food and Drugs Act]], the CPLA and the [[Canada Agricultural Products Act]], and was fined $210,000.<ref name=tpc21>[https://www.thepacker.com/article/ontario-greenhouse-group-responds-amco-verdict thepacker.com: ``Ontario greenhouse group responds to Amco verdict''], 21 Mar 2018</ref> The individuals were let off in exchange for the guilty plea.<ref name=ws13/> The sentence included "intrusive" probation for a period of time under which the CFIA gains "unfettered" access to company records.<ref name=ws13/> The case began when the CFIA did in February 2013 a random inspection at the Ontario Food Terminal. Greenhouse peppers had been fraudulently mislabelled as Ontario produce at a time of year that was too cold for greenhouses to operate. The case covered offenses that occurred over a two-year span of time.<ref name=tpc20>[https://www.thepacker.com/article/canadian-company-fined-mislabeling-mexican-produce thepacker.com: ``Canadian company fined for mislabeling Mexican produce''], 20 Mar 2018</ref><ref name=ws13>[http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/amco-produce-fined-210k-for-passing-off-foreign-vegetables-as-canadian windsorstar.com: "AMCO Produce fined $210K for passing off foreign vegetables as Canadian"], 13 Mar 2018</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Canadian federal legislation]] [[Category:Canadian business law]]

{{Infobox Officeholder |image = |name= Daniel Guin "Dan" Kyle |caption= |office=[[Louisiana]] Legislative Auditor |term_start=1989 |term_end=2003 |preceded=Joseph H. Burris |succeeded=[[Steve Theriot]] |birth_date={{birth date and age|1937|08|29}} |birth_place= |death_date= |death_place= |spouse=Connie Musick Kyle |children=Alfred Daniel Kyle
Ronald Glen Kyle |residence=[[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], [[East Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana|East Baton Rouge Parish]], Louisiana, USA |party=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |religion=[[United Methodist]] |alma_mater=[[Southern Arkansas University]]
[[University of Arkansas]] |occupation= [[Certified Public Accountant]]
Former [[Louisiana State University]] professor |footnotes= }} '''Daniel Guin Kyle''', known as '''Dan Kyle''' (born August 29, 1937), is a businessman from [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]] Louisiana, who served as his state's legislative auditor from 1989–2003,{{cite web|url=http://www.lla.state.la.us/about/history/|title=About Our Office: History|publisher=lla.state.la.us|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} when he stepped down to run unsuccessfully for insurance commissioner. An active [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], Kyle uncovered many instances of misappropriations in state and local governments during his fifteen years as auditor. He planned to run for [[governor of Louisiana|governor]] in 2003,{{cite web|url=http://www.lpb.org/programs/swi/swi2600.html|title=Interview with Dan Kyle, January 23, 2003|publisher=lpb.org|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} but he switched to the insurance commissioner race, when another Republican candidate for that office, [[Tony Perkins (politician)|Tony Perkins]], a [[Louisiana State Legislature|state representative]] from [[East Baton Rouge Parish]], abandoned the campaign to become president of the [[Family Research Council]]. As legislative auditor, Kyle posted an office sign "In God We Trust, All Others We Audit." His work uncovered [[embezzlement|embezzlers]], [[cronyism]], and [[Political corruption#Kickbacks|political kickbacks]]. His office moved against the late Elections Commissioner [[Jerry Fowler|Jerry M. Fowler]], indicted and convicted of receiving kickbacks from voting-machine contractors. Kyle investigated several college presidents but stressed that he does not believe in dismissing academic heads solely because of problems with an audit, as such positions are multi-faceted in scope.{{cite web|url=http://diverseeducation.com/article/705/state-auditor-kyle-doesn-t-enjoy-playing-the-bad-guy.html|title=Scott Dyer, "State Auditor Kyle Doesn't Enjoy Playing the Bad Guy", July 6, 2000|publisher=diverseeducation.com|accessdate=November 23, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Kyle's work led to the conviction of nearly 250 public officials and government employees for the misappropriation of state funds.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=6420|title=Our Campaigns: Dan Kyle|publisher=ourcampaigns.com|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} Prior to his auditor's position, Kyle, both a PhD and a [[Certified Public Accountant|C.P.A.]], taught governmental [[accounting]] and auditing from 1968-1989 at [[Louisiana State University]] in Baton Rouge. In 2000, Kyle uncovered serious problems with an audit of [[historically black]] [[Grambling State University]] in [[Grambling, Louisiana|Grambling]] in [[Lincoln Parish, Louisiana|Lincoln Parish]]. A 1998 audit of the same institution uncovered no problems, but two years later, the auditor received inaccurate and incomplete information from the university administration. Grambling had four months of data missing, which rendered it impossible to conduct the required two-year audit. In 1998, Kyle was invited by [[Leo Deslatte]], the new Republican mayor of [[Pineville, Louisiana|Pineville]] in [[Rapides Parish, Louisiana|Rapides Parish]], to conduct an audit of the previous [[Fred Baden]] administration. While Kyle's report found [[malfeasance]] regarding Baden's management, [[state Attorney General]] [[Richard Ieyoub]] declared insufficient evidence of wrongdoing to bring about an indictment of the 28-year Democratic mayor.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetowntalk.com/article/20091218/NEWS01/912180323/-1/NEWSFRONT2/7-term-Pineville-Mayor-Fred-Baden-remembered-for-big-heart|title=Bret H. McCormick, "7-term Pineville Mayor Fred Baden remembered for 'big heart'", December 18, 2009|publisher=''[[The Town Talk (Alexandria)|Alexandria Daily Town Talk]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In the [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] held on October 4, 2003 for insurance commissioner, Kyle trailed the Democrat [[J. Robert Wooley]], 424,961 (33.7 percent) to 467,084 (37.1 percent). Four lesser-known candidates held the remaining but critical 30 percent of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://www400.sos.louisiana.gov:8090/cgibin/?rqstyp=elcms2&rqsdta=100403|title=Louisiana election returns, October 4, 2003|publisher=sos.louisiana.gov|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In the general election, Wooley defeated Kyle, 773,578 (57.7 percent) to 567,034 (42.3 percent). Kyle won only a quartet of the more Republican parishes, [[Bossier Parish, Louisiana|Bossier]], [[Lafayette Parish, Louisiana|Lafayette]], [[Livingston Parish, Louisiana|Livingston]], and [[St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana|St. Tammany]].{{cite web|url=http://www400.sos.louisiana.gov:8090/cgibin/?rqstyp=elcms2&rqsdta=111503|title=Louisiana election returns, November 15, 2003|publisher=sos.louisiana.gov|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Kyle is a member of the East Baton Rouge Parish Republican Executive Committee. In 2007, as the deputy chairman of the [[Louisiana Republican Party]] under chairman [[Roger F. Villere, Jr.]], Kyle worked for the unsuccessful GOP candidate for Louisiana [[attorney general]], [[Royal Alexander]] of [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], who was handily defeated by the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], [[Buddy Caldwell]] of [[Tallulah, Louisiana|Tallulah]]. The GOP claimed that Caldwell spent public funds for personal uses and that he cursed and threatened Dan Kyle.{{cite web|url=http://centrallapolitics.blogspot.com/2007/10/continuing-smear-campaign-of-dan-kyle.html|title=Central La. Politics: "Continuing Smear Campaign of Dan Kyle against Buddy Caldwell", October 7, 2007|publisher=centrallapolitics.blogspot.com|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} In 2008, Kyle along with another Republican, Wayne Carter, a parish council member, and a Democrat, Ron Johnson, ran unsuccessfully for the mayor-presidency of East Baton Rouge Parish but was handily defeated by the [[incumbent]] Democrat [[Kip Holden]], an African American who scored his second term in the executive office. Kyle called for the establishment of a public bus system to help with traffic congestion.{{cite web|url= http://www.wafb.com/global/story.asp?S=9063445|title=Keitha Nelson, "Mayoral candidates outline transportation ideas", September 24, 2008|publisher=[[WAFB-TV]] News|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} Kyle criticized Holden's bond issue as an example of "tax-and-spend philosophy."{{cite web|url=http://www.225batonrouge.com/news/2008/aug/28/kips-taxing-plan/|title=Jeremy Alford, "Kip's taxing plan", August 28, 2009|publisher=225batonrouge.com|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} Kyle ran a weak second in the mayor-parish presidency, having polled 12,886 votes (12.2 percent). Holden received 75,450 (71.2 percent) and Carter polled 11,341 (10.7 percent).{{cite web|url=http://www400.sos.louisiana.gov:8090/cgibin/?rqstyp=elcpr&rqsdta=10040817|title=Louisiana election returns, October 4, 2008|publisher=sos.louisiana.gov|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Holden won in 2004 when he defeated the incumbent Republican Mayor-President [[Bobby Simpson (Louisiana politician)|Bobby R. Simpson]]. In June 2009, as treasurer of the Louisiana GOP, Kyle became one of the directors of a national [[U.S. President|presidential]] fund-raising effort promoting Governor [[Bobby Jindal]]. According to Kyle, the group hopes to raise $60 million to persuade Jindal to seek the 2012 party nomination.{{cite web|url=http://www.2theadvocate.com/news/48123092.html|title=Michelle Millhollon, "Official pulls out of Jindal group", June 16, 2009|publisher=''[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|Baton Rouge Morning Advocate]]''|accessdate=November 23, 2009}} Others on the committee are former State Representative [[Woody Jenkins]] and [[U.S. Representative]] [[Steve Scalise]]. Former Republican [[Louisiana State Legislature|State Senator]] [[Tom Schedler]] of [[Slidell, Louisiana|Slidell]], had his name removed from the group, not because he opposes Jindal but because such fund-raising activity could conflict with Schedler's role as first assistant to Louisiana Secretary of State [[Jay Dardenne]]. In October 2009, Kyle was named chief financial officer for Southern Star Amusement, Inc., a startup company which seeks to redevelop the [[Six Flags New Orleans]] theme park, closed since [[Hurricane Katrina]] struck in August 2005. Southern Star plans to construct a water and theme park at the former Six Flags site.{{cite web|url=http://www.wbrz.com/news/former-legislative-auditor-gets-new-position/|title="Former legislative auditor gets new position", October 20, 2009|publisher=[[WBRZ-TV]] News|accessdate=November 23, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723003132/http://www.wbrz.com/news/former-legislative-auditor-gets-new-position/#|archive-date=2011-07-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} Kyle, whose place of birth is not known, entered the work force at the age of fourteen in 1951, at the time of his father's death. He laid bricks and worked in retail to provide for his family and to earn his way through college. He is married to the former Connie Musick (born 1943). The couple has two sons, Alfred Daniel Kyle (born 1966) and Ronald Glen Kyle (born 1969), both of Baton Rouge. At some point prior to coming to Baton Rouge, Kyle had resided in [[Huntsville, Alabama|Huntsville]], Alabama.People Search & Background Check Kyle received his Bachelor of Science in accounting in 1959 from [[Southern Arkansas University]] in [[Magnolia, Arkansas|Magnolia]]. He then procured an [[MBA]] in 1961 and a Ph.D. in business administration in 1968, both from the [[University of Arkansas]] at [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville]]. The Kyles are active in the First [[United Methodist]] Church of Baton Rouge since they moved to the state capital in 1968. In his 2003 race for insurance commissioner, Kyle summed up his political motivation, accordingly. "Louisiana is my home. ... Louisiana is my passion. Hard economic times has split up too many families and forced our children to search for jobs in other states. ... I will fight to keep our children and grandchildren in Louisiana . . . it will take my experience, integrity, and leadership to rid this state of corruption, create an economic climate for growth, and get this state off the bottom." {{Portal|Biography|Arkansas|Louisiana|Politics|Conservatism|Education}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box |before=Joseph H. Burris |title=[[Louisiana]] Legislative Auditor Daniel Guin "Dan" Kyle |years=1989–2003| after=[[Steve Theriot]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kyle, Dan}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Politicians from Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Louisiana Republicans]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Southern Arkansas University alumni]] [[Category:University of Arkansas alumni]] [[Category:Louisiana State University faculty]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Southern Methodists]] [[Category:American United Methodists]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Dimitrios Giannakopoulos | caption = | birth_name = Dimitrios Giannakopoulos | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|6|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Athens]], [[Greece]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Athens]], [[Attica]], [[Greece]] | nationality = {{flagicon|Greece}} Greek | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = Owner of '''DPG Group'''
Vice President of '''[[Vianex]]'''
Owner of '''[[Panathinaikos B.C.]]'''
President of '''[[Panathinaikos AO]]''' | networth = €975 million (2015) | title = | salary = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = [[Pavlos Giannakopoulos]] (father) | relatives = [[Thanasis Giannakopoulos]] (uncle) | signature = | website = http://www.vianex.gr/ | footnotes = }} '''Dimitrios Pavlos Giannakopoulos''' (alternate spellings: Dimitris Giannacopoulos) ([[Greek language|Greek]]: Δημήτρης Παύλος Γιαννακόπουλος) is a [[Greece|Greek]] [[businessman]], vice-president of the Board of Directors and Deputy CEO of [[Vianex S.A.|VIANEX]] and major shareholder of [[Greek Basket League]] club [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos Athens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vianex.gr/etairia/sub-diarthrwsh.|title=Vianex|website=Vianex.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} == Biographical information == Dimitris Giannakopoulos is [[Pavlos Giannakopoulos]]’ son and [[Thanasis Giannakopoulos]]’s nephew, owners of [[Vianex S.A.|VIANEX]], the largest Greek pharmaceutical company today. The family’s engagement in the pharmaceutical sector began with his grandfather, Dimitris Giannakopoulos from [[Sellasia]] in [[Laconia]], who in 1924 opened a pharmacy in the centre of Athens. In 1971, Pavlos Giannakopoulos founded VIANEX. In 2012, despite the Greek financial crisis, the company announced net sales of up to €240,200,000. He is now the heir of the dynasty built by his father and his uncles, including both VIANEX and [[Panathinaikos B.C.]], marking the emergence of the new generation in particularly difficult times. In 2004, he was made first vice-president at VIANEX, while since January 2012, he has also assumed the office of Deputy CEO. He is married to Ioanna Marosouli, with whom he has two children. == Business activity == Dimitris Giannakopoulos took on the family business from his father, Pavlos, in January 2012, when he became Deputy CEO, additionally to being vice-president of the Board of Directors of VIANEX. The company entered the new era under Dimitris Giannakopoulos' management, that was connected with the increase of openness and the conclusion of important deals, either new ones or renewals of old ones. In July 2013, on the occasion of the announcement of the cooperation between VIANEX and [[Eli Lilly and Company|Eli Lilly]], for the production of the inject-able antibiotic Vancomycin on the premises of VIANEX in China, and the export of 100% of the production to the Chinese market, Pavlos Giannakopoulos stated: "I handed over to him the reigns of the largest Greek pharmaceutical company in the country, and I am convinced he will someday turn it into the largest pharmaceutical company even abroad". VIANEX's goals include expansion to other foreign markets as well, such as [[South Korea]], [[Vietnam]], [[Japan]], and Arabic countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.report24.gr/giannakopoulos-epektasi-tis-vianex-se-megales-agores.htm|title=Γιαννακόπουλος… “Επέκταση της ΒΙΑΝΕΞ σε Μεγάλες Αγορές” : Νέα και Ειδήσεις Λακωνίας Πελοπόννησος Report24 – η Εφημερίδα σας|website=Report24.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}}[http://www.healthview.gr/%CF%80%CE%B5%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%B5%CF%87%CF%8C%CE%BC%CE%B5%CE%BD%CE%BF/%CE%AC%CF%81%CE%B8%CF%81%CE%BF/6843/%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%AE%CF%84%CF%81%CE%B7%CF%82-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BA%CF%8C%CF%80%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BB%CE%BF] {{dead link|date=July 2018}} VIANEX received an award for its export orientation in the Active Greece Awards 2015. Furthermore, its portfolio comprises other significant awards, such as the [[Diamonds of the Greek Economy]] business award in 2013 and 2015, as well as Salux Index 2014. It is worth mentioning also the award in the Health & Safety Awards 2015, for the best practices in Health and Security in the workplace. The company won the "VIANEX Integrated Health and Safety Quality Program", the ultimate distinction in the "Pharmaceutical Companies" business sector.{{cite web|url=http://www.capital.gr/story/2155825|title=Βιανέξ - Λίλλυ: 'Made in Greece' φάρμακα στην Κίνα|website=Capital.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tovima.gr/finance/article/?aid=649983|title=tovima.gr - Τα φάρμακα από την ελληνική ΒΙΑΝΕΞ ταξιδεύουν στην Κίνα|website=Tovima.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.onmed.gr/farmako/item/321906-vravefsi-gia-tin-vianeks-sta-salus-index-2014#ixzz3pDekvVJs|title=Βράβευση για την ΒΙΑΝΕΞ στα «Salus Index 2014»|first=Νατάσσα Ν.|last=Σπαγαδώρου|date=13 November 2014|website=Onmed.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} As Dimitris Giannakopoulos has stated to the press on numerous occasions, VIANEX neither let any employees go, nor did it decrease salaries, despite the financial crisis in Greece. The economic size of VIANEX shrunk; however, its employees "have stood by the company and contributed to achieving high profits over the last years. Thus we, the management, are obligated to support our people, regardless of the economic performance", Dimitris Giannakopoulos stated in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.kathimerini.gr/791939/article/oikonomia/epixeirhseis/ta3ideyoyn-sthn-kina-ta-farmaka-ths-viane3|title=Ταξιδεύουν στην Κίνα τα φάρμακα της Βιανέξ - Kathimerini|website=Kathimerini.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.ygeia360.gr/el/companies/item/17815-diamonds-of-the-greek-economy-2015-diakrish-gia-thn-bianex-# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-11-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120060558/http://www.ygeia360.gr/el/companies/item/17815-diamonds-of-the-greek-economy-2015-diakrish-gia-thn-bianex-# |archive-date=2015-11-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{Cite web |url=http://kourdistoportocali.com/post/21727/dhm-giannakopoylos-bianeks-gt-to-manifesto-toy-epixeirhmatia-sthn-ekdhlwsh-ths-statbank-diamonds-2013# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-11-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120010947/http://kourdistoportocali.com/post/21727/dhm-giannakopoylos-bianeks-gt-to-manifesto-toy-epixeirhmatia-sthn-ekdhlwsh-ths-statbank-diamonds-2013# |archive-date=2015-11-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == Social contribution == Dimitris Giannakopoulos has engaged in a series of important initiatives with the intention to contribute to Greek society through VIANEX, [[Panathinaikos B.C.]], and the electronic media company DPG Group, which he also owns. To raise awareness among the population, regarding the issue of cardiovascular disease, VIANEX donated 15,000 bad cholesterol tests within the context of the extended Panhellenic Patient Support Project "Measure LDL with us", under the auspices of the Hellenic Society of Lipidology, Atherosclerosis and Vascular Disease (E.E.L.I.A.).{{cite web|url=http://www.stogiatro.gr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=35915:vianeks-dwrean-eksetaseis-xolhsterolhs-se-olh-thn-ellada&catid=370:etairika-nea&Itemid=242|title=stogiatro - ΒΙΑΝΕΞ: Δωρεάν εξετάσεις χοληστερόλης σε όλη την Ελλάδα|website=Stogiatro.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} Also, VIANEX donated 300 vaccines to the Social Clinic and Pharmacy of the diocese of Arkalochori, Kastelli & Viannos, and the Municipality of Minoa Pediadas in Crete, aiming to defend child health, as well as safeguard public health. DPG offered support to the Mitera - Centre for Child Protection of Attica; its people visited the infant centre and the dormitories of the premises, to give away presents for Christmas, such as candy, clothes, shoes, Sudocream lotions, as well as [[Panathinaikos]] blankets from the PAO Shop.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsbomb.gr/ellada/news/story/384368/dpg-digital-media--kai-panathinaikos-sto-pleyro-toy-idrymatos-mitera|title=DPG Digital Media και Παναθηναϊκός στο πλευρό του ιδρύματος «Μητέρα»|first=|last=Newsbomb|date=20 December 2013|website=Newsbomb.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}}{{Cite web |url=http://biologikaorganikaproionta.com/health/145653/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-11-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120014220/http://biologikaorganikaproionta.com/health/145653/# |archive-date=2015-11-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Also, it responded to the invitation of [[Make-A-Wish Foundation|Make-a-Wish foundation]] (Make-a-Wish Greece), by taking part in the charity dinner organized at the [[Benaki Museum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newsbomb.gr/ellada/news/story/600260/mia-eyxi-poy-egine-pragmatikotita|title=Μια ...ευχή που έγινε πραγματικότητα|first=|last=Newsbomb|date=25 June 2015|website=Newsbomb.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} Panathinaikos B.C. and Dimitris Giannakopoulos donated five cutting-edge wheelchairs to the Patriotic Institution of Social Welfare (PIKPA) of Voula, for the basketball team of the institution during the National Championship of Wheelchair Basketball. The President of the Panhellenic Association of Paraplegics (PA.S.PA) awarded Dimitris Giannakopoulos for his social contribution.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsitamea.gr/%CE%9F-%CE%94-%CE%93%CE%B9%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BA%CF%8C%CF%80%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BB%CE%BF%CF%82-%CE%B4%CF%8E%CF%81%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%B5-%CF%80%CE%AD%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B5-%CE%B1%CE%BC%CE%B1%CE%BE%CE%AF|title=Ο Δ.Γιαννακόπουλος δώρισε πέντε αμαξίδια τελευταίας τεχνολογίας στο ΠΙΚΠΑ Βούλας - Newsitamea|date=21 September 2013|website=Newsitamea.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} Dimitris Giannakopoulos donated specialized equipment of €50,000 in worth to the Underwater Operations Unit of the Hellenic Coast Guard. The Head of the [[Hellenic Coast Guard]], Vice Admiral Athanasios Athanasopoulos, and the Commander of Special Forces, Captain Alexios Karakoulas, awarded Giannakopoulos with an honorary coat of arms for his contribution.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.gr/basketball/article/598067/dorea-sto-limeniko-kai-vraveysi-d-giannakopoyloy-pics|title=Δωρέα στο Λιμενικό και βράβευση Δ. Γιαννακόπουλου (pics)|website=Gazzetta.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} He donated also 55 fluorescent wind-proof jackets to the Road Traffic Police of the Attica Tollway ([[Attiki Odos]]), to help upgrade their equipment, and the facilitation of the work of the police officers, in the presence of the Colonel of the Road Traffic Police, Brigadier General D. Papanagiotou and the Commander of the Road Traffic Police Unit of the Attica Tollway, Police Second Lieutenant E. Kountouromichalis. The Colonel of the Road Traffic Police thanked Mr. Giannakopoulos, offering him an honorary badge.{{cite web|url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/430928/dorea-tou-d-giannakopoulou-sto-tmima-trohaias-attikis-odou/|title=Δωρεά του Δ. Γιαννακόπουλου στο Τμήμα Τροχαίας Αττικής Οδού|website=Protothema.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} In the context of the VIANEX contribution, Dimitris Giannakopoulos donated to the [[Hellenic Police]] 10 high-performance motorcycles. == Panathinaikos B.C. == In 2012, Dimitris Giannakopoulos took charge of Panathinaikos B.C., after his father, Pavlos, and his uncle, Thanasis, who managed the club before him. During his Presidency, the team won two consecutive Greek doubles ([[Greek Basket League]] championship and [[Greek Basketball Cup|Greek Cup]]). However, in December 2014, he resigned from the club's President position, giving his seat to Manos Papadopoulos. He claimed to have been forced to proceed to such a move because of the constant sanctions and fines imposed on the club by the Greek State.{{cite web|url=http://www.sport-fm.gr/article/basket/giannakopoulos/796870|title=Αποχώρησε… τυπικά από την ΚΑΕ ο Γιαννακόπουλος!|website=Sport-fm.gr|accessdate=29 July 2018}} == Media involvement == In recent years, Dimitris Giannakopoulos has created a Media Group in cooperation with DPG Digital Media, which is a series of websites of political, sport, medical, and social content, including the sports websites onsports.gr and leoforos.gr, the medical website onmed.gr, and many more. The long-standing success in the management of web communication media for DPG was sealed by its cooperation with [[CNN]]. === CNN Greece === DPG, along with the international news giant [[CNN]], established [http://www.cnn.gr CNN.gr]. Dimitris Giannakopoulos, the President of DPG Group, stated on the occasion of the cooperation announcement: "We are particularly pleased to become members of the international CNN family through this strategic cooperation. CNN.gr aims to provide to the Greek-speaking audience immediate and accurate Greek and international news, with the unique seal of quality provided by CNN, bringing at the same time the Greek diaspora closer to the motherland. In times marked by very important developments for Greece, we invest in a platform which will responsibly serve the increasing demand of the audience for accurate, timely, and quality information."{{cite web|url=http://cnnpressroom.blogs.cnn.com/2015/07/30/cnn-gr-to-launch-online-and-on-mobile/|title=CNN.GR TO LAUNCH ONLINE AND ON MOBILE|website=cnnpressroom.blogs.cnn.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} == Sparta F.C. == Giannakopoulos was also the main financial contributor to the Greek [[association football|football]] club [[Sparta F.C.]], which competes in the [[Football League (Greece)|Greek football second division]], and which is based in [[Sparta (modern)|Sparta]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.vianex.gr/Default.aspx?ID=43 Vianex website] *[http://www.paobc.gr/page.ashx?pid=17&aid=3173&mid=78&lang=2 Panathinaikos B.C. website profile] {{Panathinaikos}} {{Panathinaikos BC}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Giannakopoulos, Dimitrios}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Panathinaikos B.C.]] [[Category:Panathinaikos B.C. presidents]] [[Category:Greek basketball chairmen and investors]] [[Category:Greek football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:Greek volleyball chairmen and investors]] [[Category:1974 births]]

The '''Electricity Association''' ('''EA''')<ref>{{cite web|title=EA - Electricity Association|url=http://www.managenergy.net/actors/1070|website=[[ManagEnergy]]|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref> was an association of major [[electricity]] companies in the [[United Kingdom]].
It closed on September 30, 2003,<ref>[http://www.energynetworks.org/assets/files/electricity/she/safelec_2010/SAFELEC_2003.pdf SAFEELEC 2010, Energy Networks Association, March 2004]</ref> and its services were replaced by three other industry bodies:<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jeremy de Souza|author2=John Snape|title=Environmental Taxation Law: Policy, Contexts and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Au7QwbSqVgYC&pg=PT158|date=28 January 2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-9317-4|pages=158–}}</ref> * [[Association of Electricity Producers]] * [[Energy Networks Association (United Kingdom)|Energy Networks Association]] * [[Energy Retail Association]]
==See also== *[http://www.ena-eng.org/ENA-Docs/ Energy Networks Association Document Catalogue], includes documents of the former Electricity Association
== References ==

page.title: European Union Chamber of Commerce in China

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name= European Union Chamber of Commerce in China |established= October 19, 2000 | logo = EUCC-China-logo.png | logo_size = 200px | logo_alt = EUCC China logo | logo_caption = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Mats Harborn | board_of_directors = | key_people = Mats Harborn (President), Patrick Horgan (Vice-president), Massimo Bagnasco (Vice-president), (Vice-president), Michael Chang (Vice-president), Carlo Diego D'Andrea (Vice-president), George Lau (Vice-president), Lars Eckerlein (Treasurer), Adam Dunnett (Secretary General). | mission = | affiliations = [[Beijing]], [[Nanjing]], [[South China]], [[Shanghai]], [[Shenyang]], [[Southwest China]], [[Tianjin]] Chapters | slogan = Information, communication, networking | founder = [[European Union]] companies in China | founding_location = | extinction = | merger = | type = [[non-profit organisation]], [[chamber of commerce]] | tax_id = | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = Active | purpose = [[International trade]] | headquarters = [[Beijing|Beijing, China]] | location = | coords = | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = Finance and socially responsible investment, health and safety, philanthropy and charity, social standards and labor protection (supply chain), labor protection (supply chain). | membership = 1600 | membership_year = | languages = English, Chinese | owner = | sec_gen = Adam Dunnett |website = [http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/home www.europeanchamber.com.cn] }}
The '''European Union Chamber of Commerce in China''', [[doing business as]] '''European Chamber''', is a [[non-profit organisation|non-profit]] and [[non-governmental organisation]] established to support and represent the interests of companies from the [[European Union]] operating in [[China]].<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/china/economy/article/2111777/action-not-words-needed-foreign-access-china-markets-says-chamber |title= Action not words needed on foreign access to China markets, says chamber |newspaper= [[South China Morning Post]] |date=2017-09-19 |access-date= }}</ref><ref name="cnbc"/> The main objective of the European Chamber is to inform its members, facilitate communication and [[regulatory compliance]] in the Chinese environment and advocate equal treatment of its members.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.ft.com/content/a7215292-02e4-11e7-ace0-1ce02ef0def9 |title= European businesses attack China high-tech push |newspaper= [[Financial Times]] |date=2017-03-07 |access-date= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.dailysabah.com/business/2018/01/18/politics-in-china-weighs-heavily-on-businesses |title= Politics in China weighs heavily on businesses |newspaper= [[Daily Sabah]] |date=2018-01-17 |access-date= }}</ref> The organization is headquartered in [[Beijing|Beijing, China]].
==Organization==
The European Chamber has more than 1,600 members from seven chapters active in nine Chinese cities including [[Beijing]], [[Nanjing]], [[South China]] ([[Guangzhou]] and [[Shenzhen]]), [[Shanghai]], [[Shenyang]], [[Southwest China]] ([[Chengdu]] and [[Chongqing]]) and [[Tianjin]]. The European Chamber is recognized by the [[Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China]] and the [[China Council for the Promotion of International Trade]] (CCPIT), and is registered with the [[Ministry of Civil Affairs]] (MCA).
===Executive Committee=== The executive committee of the European Chamber consists of a president, five vice presidents, a treasurer, three member states' representatives and the European Chamber's Secretary General. Representatives of member companies are elected for a two-year term renewable once.
===Supervisory Board=== The supervisory board of the European Chamber consists of member representatives who elect three persons to represent the group on the executive committee. In addition to creating an electoral college, the supervisory board meets regularly to monitor and guide the work of the executive committee. The national representatives are nominated by national chambers of commerce or embassies by default.
===Secretariat=== The secretariat of the European Chamber is responsible for the daily operations and activities.
==Publications== As a common platform for information and cooperation, the European Chamber publishes magazines and reports about the current experience of European businesses in China. These publications provide insights into current markets, key regulatory issues, industry-expert opinions, and notable social trends in China.
* Eurobiz Journal of the European Chamber of Commerce in China.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/eurobiz-magazine |title= EUROBIZ MAGAZINE - NOVEMBER/DECEMBER 2017 |website= EUCCC |access-date= }}</ref> * EUCCC Annual Report.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/publications-annual-report |title= Annual Report 2016 |website= EUCCC |access-date= }}</ref> * China Manufacturing 2025.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/china-manufacturing-2025 |title= CHINA MANUFACTURING 2025: PUTTING INDUSTRIAL POLICY AHEAD OF MARKET FORCES |website= EUCCC |date= }}</ref> * Dulling the Cutting Edge.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/publications-patent-policy-innovation-in-china-study#download-table-129 |title= Dulling the Cutting Edge: How Patent-Related Policies and Practices Hamper Innovation |author = Dan Prud'homme (IPR Working Group / R&D Forum – Shangai Chapter) |website= EUCCC |date= December 17, 2012}}</ref> * The Social and Economic Impact of Private Equity in China.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/publications-private-equity-in-china-2012 |title= The Social and Economic Impact of Private Equity in China |author = Strategic Mergers & Acquisitions Working Group |website= EUCCC |date= June 30, 2012}}</ref> * Overcapacity in China.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/publications-overcapacity-in-china#download-table-163 |title= Overcapacity in China: An Impediment to the Party's Reform Agenda |author = |website= EUCCC |date= February 2016}}</ref> * Public procurement in China.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/publications-public-procurement-study-european-business-experiences-competing-for-public-contracts-in-china |title= Public procurement in China |author = Public Procurement Working Group, Healthcare Equipment Working Group, ICT Working Group, Renewable Energy Sub-Working Group, Legal Working Group. |website= EUCCC |date= November 1, 2011}}</ref>
==History==
The European Chamber was founded on 19 October 2000, by 51 European companies in search of a common representative of their interests in China. The Chamber is also part of an expanding network of European Business Organisation Worldwide Network (EBOWWN). This network promotes interactions between members and host countries and establish closer relationships with the Commission. The original purpose of the Chamber was to monitor how China implemented its WTO commitments.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2006/july/tradoc_129275.pdf |title= A View from EU Business in China |author = EU Business in China |website= |date= }}</ref> According to the Chamber: "Foreign firms have long complained of an uneven playing field and an opaque regulatory environment when it comes to China."<ref name="cnbc">{{Cite news |url= https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/18/china-market-european-group-urges-beijing-to-open-up.html |title= European group urges China to actually open up markets like it says it will |newspaper= [[CNBC]] |date=2017-09-18 |access-date= }}</ref>
==Mission==
The European Chamber is an organization that aims for better market access and improved operating conditions for the European Union companies operating in China. To this end, it reaches out to Chinese and European government authorities,<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.ft.com/content/80fd0c48-bbf4-11e4-a6d7-00144feab7de |title= China needs to be placed at the top of the European Commission's 'to do' list |newspaper= [[Financial Times]] |date=2014-11-04 |access-date= }}</ref> [[think tank]]s, academics, international bodies, other chambers of commerce and trade associations. The Chamber ensures awareness and compliance with relevant local [[law]]s, policies, and [[regulations]]. It also [[Facilitation (business)|facilitates]] networking between its members, embassies and Chinese interest groups. They oversee a network of companies and professionals, help them exchange views and experiences regarding doing business in China. The European Chamber is primarily an [[Advocacy group|advocacy organization]] that evolves around [[working groups]] and foras. These groups serve as a platform for the Chamber community and other local organizations, to foster understanding, share information, pursue common interests, promote trade and investment, and strengthen cooperation.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.ft.com/content/80fd0c48-bbf4-11e4-a6d7-00144feab7de |title= Europe dares to talk tough with China regulators |newspaper= [[Financial Times]] |date=2015-02-24 |access-date= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2017-09/19/content_32207186.htm |title= EU body urges China to accelerate opening up |newspaper= [[China Daily]] |date=2017-09-19 |access-date= }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.europeanchamber.com.cn/en/home EUCCC official website] *[https://www.ebowwn.com/ EBO Worldwide Network website]

{{for|the Scottish [[electoral reform]] campaign|Fairshare}} {{Primary sources|date=December 2007}}
'''FairShare''' is an idea for a voluntary [[investment]]-based [[patronage]] system to replace [[patents]] and [[copyright]] while still ensuring that artists are fairly compensated. It was designed by [[Freenet]] creator [[Ian Clarke (computer scientist)|Ian Clarke]], [[Steven Starr]] and Rob Kramer in 2000, in response to allegations that artists would not receive adequate compensation for their work without enforceable copyrights. Starr came up with the name.
In the FairShare system, the investor/patrons would provide [[venture capital]]. Clarke envisions that 45% of the money invested in a given artist would go directly to that artist, while another 45% would be given to previous investors. The remaining 10% would be kept by the maintainers of each FairShare service company.
In some ways this model is similar to a [[pyramid scheme]], but Clarke counters that a vital difference is that nobody would be promised a return on their investment. He argues that regardless of any profits, each patron would have the satisfaction of knowing that they supported an artist whose work they appreciate. Also, earlier investors would profit more, thus rewarding them for investing in artists before they became more popular. The early investors would serve a similar role to studios' talent scouts.
==See also== *[[Anti-copyright]] *[[Copynorms]] *[[Share-alike]] *[[Copyleft]] *[[Copyright-free]] *[[Creative Commons]] *[[File sharing]] :*[[Peer-to-peer]] *[[Gift economy]] *[[Fund and release]] *[[Open Music Model]] *[[Public domain]]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070314205708/http://freenetproject.org/fairshare.html Ian Clarke's original essay on FairShare].
[[Category:Intellectual property law]]

'''ISKO''' is a textile manufacturer and distributor and the world’s largest producer of [[denim]], producing over 250 million meters of denim annually,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fashionmagazine.it/ItemByCategory.aspx?ItemID=33046|title=Il colosso del denim Isko chiuderà il 2012 in crescita a doppia cifra|publisher=''fashionmagazine.it''}}</ref><ref name="jenniferrooney">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferrooney/2014/02/24/isko-steps-out-as-premium-denim-ingredient-brand/|title=Isko Steps Out As Premium Denim Ingredient Brand|author=Jennifer Rooney|date=24 February 2014|publisher=''Forbes''}}</ref> which it distributes to more than 60 countries worldwide.
== History == ISKO was founded in 1983 as a division of Sanko Textile Industries, a member of Sanko Group, a family-held, diversified, multinational company, with 12 divisions, including textiles, renewable energy, construction, packaging and financial activities.
Sanko Textile Industries was founded in 1904 by Sani Konukoğlu, who started the company with a single hand-loom. In 1943, his grandson, Sani Konukoğlu, inherited the business and expanded the textiles division, founding the current parent company, Sanko Group<ref>{{cite web|title=Sanko Holding A.S.: CEO and Executives - Businessweek|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/people.asp?privcapId=24438513|publisher=''Businessweek.com''}}</ref>
== Leadership == ISKO is a family-run business, led by sons of Sanko Group’s founder Sani Konukoğlu: CEO, Fatih Konukoğlu, who graduated from Bolton University with a degree in Textile Engineering; Abdülkadir Konukoglu, honorary Chairman of the Board of Sanko Group; and Zekeriye Konukoglu, President of Sanko Group.<ref>http://www.gaziantephaberler.com/grevin-ilk-kaybedeni-abdulkadir-konukoglu-haberi-23878.html</ref>
== Research == ISKO’s Research & Development facility is [[Turkey]]’s first government-certified textile research center and has divisions specializing in biology, chemistry and physics research as well as textile development. ISKO-owned Iskoteca, in San Benedetto del Tronto, Italy, is a research and development lab developing new treatments and finishes.<ref>{{cite web|title = iSKO alza il sipario sul denim del futuro|url = http://tv.pambianconews.com/isko-alza-il-sipario-sul-denim-del-futuro/|publisher = ''Pambianco TV.''}}</ref> In 2011, ISKO opened a second research center in [[Castelfranco Veneto]].<ref>{{cite web|title = ISKO OPENS CONCEPT SHOWROOM - www.sportswearnet.com|url = http://www.sportswearnet.com/businessnews/pages/protected/ISKO-OPENS-CONCEPT-SHOWROOM_2619.html|publisher = ''sportswearnet.com.''}}</ref>
== Sustainability and Organic Textiles == ISKO has received certification for its sustainable products, including the [[Oeko-tex]] Standard 100 certification, the GOTS (Global Organic Textile Standard) certification for products made with 100% organic cotton, the OEP (Organic Exchange Products) certification, and the ISO 9001 & ISO 9002B certifications.<ref>{{cite web|title=ISKO™|url=http://www.denimfuture.com/brand/isko-denim|publisher=''Denim Future.''}}</ref>
== Trademarks and Patents == ISKO holds 10 international patents and patent-pending technologies with more than 35 registered and trademarked brands<ref>{{cite web|title=ISKO S.R.L. - Trademark owner|url=http://tm.kurzy.cz/isko-srl/}}</ref> including: [[Jeggings]], a hybrid of denim and legging material,<ref>{{cite web|title=İSKO™, the denim language, ottiene la registrazione dei marchi jeggings™, re call™ e smoked ™ e il diritto di uso esclusivo degli stessi|url=http://www.admirabilia.it/press_room/isko-the-denim-language-ottiene-registrazione-dei-marchi-jeggings-re-call-smoked-il-diritto-di-uso-esclusivo-degli-stessi.html|publisher=''admirabilia.it.''}}</ref> Turbotech,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.textile-network.com/technische-textilien/unique-palette_18877_en/|title=Unique Palette|publisher=''textile-network.com.''}}</ref> ISKO Future Face, Recall, a spinning technology that allows a much faster recovery than conventional fabrics,<ref>{{cite web|title=Unique Palette|url=http://www.textile-network.com/technische-textilien/unique-palette_18877_en/|publisher=''textile-network.com.''}}</ref> and ISKO Reform, a super stretch denim that incorporates a hidden synthetic inside the cotton yarn which creates a spring-like construction.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-blog/2013/oct/08/make-you-skinny-jeans-women-fashion|title=After the skinny jean, the make-you-skinny jean|author=Jess Cartner-Morley|publisher=''the Guardian.''}}</ref>
== Training & Education Initiatives == In 2013 ISKO-launched the I-SKOOL project, an annual denim industry training program and competition for designers and marketing professionals, culminating in an awards show, in collaboration with 14 international design schools, including [[Istituto Marangoni]], ESMOD Munich, Istanbul Moda Academy, [[London College of Fashion]], and [[Chelsea College of Arts]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Istanbul: ISKO Laundry Seminar|url=http://blog.stylesight.com/denim/istanbul-isko-laundry-seminar|publisher=''WGSN Blog.''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Isko launches I-Skool project - www.sportswearnet.com|url=http://www.sportswearnet.com/news/pages/protected/Isko-launches-I-Skool-project_7666.html|publisher=''sportswearnet.com''}}</ref>
ISKO participates in the biennial Copenhagen Summit, where it sponsors the Denim Challenge, which gives five emerging designers the opportunity to work at ISKO’s research and development facility in [[Castelfranco Veneto]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wgsn.com/blogs/isko–presents-creative-room/|title = ISKO Presents Creative Room|date = |accessdate = |website = WGXN INSIDER|publisher = |last = Trotman|first = Samuel}}</ref>
== Philanthropy == The Sani Konukoğlu Foundation, which was created by the Konukoğlu family in 1989, provides scholarships to more than 1,500 university students per year and supports Sani Konukoğlu Medical Center, Turkey's largest private hospital and Sanko Private Schools.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
In 2013, ISKO’s holding company, Sanko Group, established a university, The [[Sanko University]], a research university that specializes in Medical and Health Sciences with a Faculty of Medicine, Faculty of Health Sciences, Faculty of Dentistry, Institute of Health Sciences and Institute of Science and Technology.<ref>http://www.sanko.edu.tr</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
