[[File:Tontine coffee house.jpg|right|thumb|325px|A 1797 oil on linen painting by [[Francis Guy]] (1760–1820). The building sporting the American flag on its roof is the Tontine Coffee House. Diagonally opposite (southeast corner, extreme right)Hewitt, p. 31 is the Merchant's Coffee House, where the [[stockbroker]]s of the [[Buttonwood Agreement]] and others did trade before the construction of the Tontine. On the right is [[Wall Street]], leading down to the [[East River]].]] The '''Tontine Coffee House''' was a [[New York City]] [[coffee house]] established in early 1793. Situated on the north-west corner of [[Wall Street]] and Water Street,Hewitt, p. 34Nathans, p. 133 it was built by a group of [[stockbroker]]s to serve as a meeting place for trade and correspondence. It was organized as a [[tontine]], a type of investment plan, and funded by the sale of 203 shares of £200 each.[http://dlib.nyu.edu/findingaids/html/nyhs/tontine/bioghist.html Guide to the Records of the Tontine Coffee-House] The May 17, 1792, creation of the [[Buttonwood Agreement]], which bound its signatories to trade only with each other, effectively gave rise to a new organization of tradespeople.Sobel, p. 21 In its prime, the Tontine was among New York City's busiest centers for the buying and selling of stocks and other wares, for business dealings and discussion, and for political transaction.Antol, p. 53 Having had a dual function as a combination club and a meeting room, the coffee house played host to auctions, banquets, and balls, among others. After hours, gambling and securities dealings were {{nowrap|had – undertakings}} that were then deemed less than honest.Sobel, p. 22 The coffee house also provided a place for the registration of ship cargo and the [[slave trade|trading of slaves]].{{cite web|url=http://maap.columbia.edu/place/16.html|title=Place Detail – Tontine Coffeehouse|publisher=MAAP|accessdate=2009-09-11}} The Tontine was noted as classless; individuals from all social strata met there and collectively engaged in the many civil and economic affairs. John Lambert, an English traveller, wrote in 1807:Still, p. 74 :
The Tontine Coffee House was filled with underwriters, brokers, merchants, traders, and politicians; selling, purchasing, trafficking, or insuring; some reading, others eagerly inquiring the news […] The steps and balcony of the coffee-house were crowded with people bidding, or listening to the several auctioneers, who had elevated themselves upon a hogshead of sugar, a puncheon of rum, or a bale of cotton; and with Stentorian voices were exclaiming, "Once, twice. Once, twice." "Another cent." "Thank ye gentlemen." [...] The coffee-house slip, and the corners of Wall and Pearl-streets, were jammed up with carts, drays, and wheelbarrows [...] Everything was in motion; all was life, bustle and activity...
Political demonstrations and violence were not uncommon at the Tontine Coffee House. In the wake of the [[French Revolution]], fistfights between those respectively sympathetic to the British and the French broke out on a daily basis.Gilje, p. 101 An anonymous observer wrote:Gilje, p. 102 :
Whenever two or three people are gather'd together, it is expected there is a Quarrel and they crowd round, hence other squabbles arise.
On one occasion, French Revolutionists and supporters of the [[Tammany Hall]] movement scaled the coffee house and placed a [[French Liberty Cap]] on the roof.Nathans, p. 136 Several New York publications mentioned the {{nowrap|event – in}} particular, those newspapers with pro-[[Jacobin Club|Jacobin]] or pro–Democratic-Republican slants applauded the perpetrators and encouraged the Tontine's proprietors to allow the Cap to remain. In addition, an onlooker named Alexander Anderson describes conflict between [[Whig (British political party)|Whig]]s and [[Tory]]s at the Tontine in a June 11, 1793, diary entry: :
[L]ast night there was an affray at the Tontine Coffee House between Whig and Tory, or to modernize it, aristocrat and democrat.
In December 1793, New York's ''[[Columbian Gazetteer]]'' complained that "only persons of the same party" would now associate within the Tontine. Trading at the Tontine Coffee House continued until 1817.Antol, p. 52 The growth of the Tontine's trade proceedings had effected the creation of the [[New York Stock and Exchange Board]] (NYSEB) and necessitated a larger venue.Fisher, p. 59 The NYSEB is recognised as the precursor to the present-day [[New York Stock Exchange]], the largest [[stock exchange]] in the world. The Tontine itself was transformed into a tavern by a John Morse in 1826, and a hotel by [[Lovejoy & Belcher]] in 1832.Hewitt, p. 35 It survived the [[Great Fire of New York|Great Fire of 1835]] and was demolished 20 years later. ==Notes== *{{cite book|title=Confessions of a Coffee Bean: The Complete Guide to Coffee Cuisine|first=Marie Nadine|last=Antol|publisher=Square One Publishers, Inc.|year=2002|isbn=0-7570-0020-7}} *{{cite book|title=The Supply and Demand Paradox: A Treatise on Economics|first=Byron|last=Fisher|publisher=BookSurge|year=2007|isbn=1-4196-6427-1}} *{{cite book|title=The road to mobocracy: popular disorder in New York City, 1763–1834|first=Paul|last=Gilje|publisher=UNC Press|year=1987|isbn=0-8078-4198-6}} *Hewitt, Robert (Jr.) (1872). [https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=NstBAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&authuser=0&hl=en&pg=GBS.PA34 ''Coffee: Its History, Cultivation, and Uses.''] New York: D. Appleton and Company. *{{cite book|title=Early American theatre from the revolution to Thomas Jefferson: into the hands of the people|first=Heather|last=Nathans|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2003|isbn=0-521-82508-3}} *{{cite book|title=The Big Board: A History of the New York Stock Market|first=Robert|last=Sobel|publisher=Beard Books|year=2000|isbn=1-893122-66-2}} *{{cite book|title=Mirror for Gotham: New York as seen by contemporaries from Dutch days to the present|first=Bayrd|last=Still|publisher=Fordham University Press|year=1994|isbn=0-8232-1529-6}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Tontine Coffee House (Manhattan)|Tontine Coffee House}} *[http://maap.columbia.edu/image/view/772.html Photograph of the Tontine Coffee House site today] *[http://dlib.nyu.edu/findingaids/html/nyhs/tontine/ Guide to the Records of the Tontine Coffee-House, 1738-1879] {{coord|40.705486|-74.007964|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-NY|display=title}} [[Category:Coffee houses of the United States]] [[Category:New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:1793 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Wall Street]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in New York City]] [[Category:Companies established in 1793]] [[Category:Restaurants established in 1793]] [[Category:Companies disestablished in 1826]]

{{distinguish|Wall Street (IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line)}} {{Infobox NYCS | name = Wall Street | wifi = yes | image = Wall Street IRT 013.JPG | image_caption = Downtown {{rint|newyork|4}} train leaving Wall Street | bg_color = #007527 | address = Wall Street & Broadway
New York, NY 10006 | borough = [[Manhattan]] | locale = [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.70771|N|74.011717|W|display=inline,title}} | lat_dir = N | lon_dir = W | division = IRT | line = [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]] | service = Lexington south | connection = {{bus icon}} '''[[NYCT Bus]]''': {{NYC bus link|M55}}, {{NYC bus link|SIM1|SIM2|SIM4|SIM4X|SIM32|SIM34|X27|X28}}
{{bus icon}} '''[[NJT Bus]]''': {{NJ bus link|120}} | platforms = 2 [[side platform]]s | tracks = 2 | structure = Underground | code = 413 | open_date = {{start date and age|1905|June|12|mf=yes}} | passengers = 5,704,122{{NYCS const|riderref}} | pass_year = 2017 | pass_percent = -7.2 | rank = 78 | next_north = {{NYCS next | station=Fulton Street | line=IRT Lexington Avenue Line | service=Lexington south}} | next_south = {{NYCS next | station=Bowling Green | line=IRT Lexington Avenue Line | service=Lexington south}} | legend = {{NYCS infobox legend|allexceptnights}}{{NYCS infobox legend|alltimes}} | embedded = {{Infobox NRHP | name = Wall Street Subway Station (IRT) | embed = yes | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= Under Broadway at Wall Street, [[Manhattan|New York]], [[New York (state)|NY]] 10016 | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|27|N|74|0|44|W|display=inline}} | locmapin = New York City#New York#USA | built = 1905 | architect = Parsons, William Barclay; Heins, George L., et al | architecture = Beaux Arts | added = September 17, 2004 | area = less than one acre | governing_body = State | mpsub = New York City Subway System MPS | refnum = 04001011{{NRISref|version=2010a}} }} }} '''Wall Street''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]] of the [[New York City Subway]], located at the intersection of [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] and [[Wall Street (Manhattan)|Wall Street]]. It is served by the '''[[4 (New York City Subway service)|4]]''' train at all times and the '''[[5 (New York City Subway service)|5]]''' train at all times except late nights. == History == {{stack|float=right| {{NYCS 2-tracked side platform station |1=Fulton Street |l1=Fulton St |2=Bowling Green |code=IRT Lexington Avenue Line |color=Lexington |textcolor=white |dir=330 }} [[File:Wall Street Station 2889342690 577cbec82b.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Downtown entrance at Trinity Church]] }} This station opened on June 12, 1905, as a one-stop extension of the original subway from Fulton Street.{{Cite web|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/06/13/100488269.pdf|title=SUBWAY TRAINS RUN AGAIN THIS MORNING; Through Service Promised for the rush-Hour Crowds. TUNNEL PUMPED OUT AT LAST Big Water Main That Burst Was an Old One, Pressed Into Service Again After a Five-Hour Watch.|access-date=2016-09-18}}{{Cite web|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/06/07/101361854.pdf|title=SUBWAY TO WALL ST. OPEN IN TEN DAYS; And All the Way to the Bronx by July 1. WHOLE ROAD READY IN AUGUST As to the Air Therein, William Barclay Parsons Says It Is Pure and Can't Be Bettered.|access-date=2016-09-18}} On January 6, 1994, Automated Fare Collection turnstiles went into service at this station, and at the [[South Ferry–Whitehall Street (New York City Subway)|Whitehall Street]] station.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021019203759/http://www.mta.info/nyct/facts/ffhist.htm|title=About NYC Transit - History|date=2002-10-19|access-date=2016-09-18}} In 1995, as a result of service reductions, the MTA was considering permanently closing one of the two Wall Street stations, as well as two other stations citywide, due to their proximity to each other. Either the IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line or the IRT Lexington Avenue Line station would have been closed.{{cite web | last=Perez-Pena | first=Richard | title=BOARD VOTES CUTS FOR CITY TRANSIT | website=The New York Times | date=1995-02-25 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/25/nyregion/board-votes-cuts-for-city-transit.html | access-date=2018-05-16}} ==Station layout== {|table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=3 |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''G''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Street Level |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=500 valign=top|Exit/ Entrance |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=50 rowspan=4 valign=top|'''B1
Platform level''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|[[Side platform]], doors will open on the right |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|'''Northbound''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|← {{rint|newyork|4}} toward [[Woodlawn (IRT Jerome Avenue Line)|Woodlawn]] ([[Fulton Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Fulton Street]])
← {{rint|newyork|5}} toward [[Eastchester–Dyre Avenue (IRT Dyre Avenue Line)|Eastchester–Dyre Avenue]] all times except nights, or [[Nereid Avenue (IRT White Plains Road Line)|Nereid Avenue]] rush hours (Fulton Street) |- |'''Southbound''' |→ {{rint|newyork|4}} toward [[Crown Heights–Utica Avenue (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Crown Heights–Utica Avenue]] ({{rint|newyork|4}} toward [[New Lots Avenue (IRT New Lots Line)|New Lots Avenue]] late nights) ([[Bowling Green (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Bowling Green]]) →
→ {{rint|newyork|5}} toward [[Flatbush Avenue–Brooklyn College (IRT Nostrand Avenue Line)|Flatbush Avenue–Brooklyn College]] weekdays, Bowling Green weekends (Bowling Green) → |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;border-top:solid 2px black;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|[[Side platform]], doors will open on the right |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''B2''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Crossunder |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=500|Transfer between platforms, passageway to [[Broad Street (BMT Nassau Street Line)|Broad Street]] |} [[File:Wall Street IRT 005.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Downtown {{rint|newyork|5}} train of [[R142 (New York City Subway car)|R142]] cars arriving]] Wall Street is an underground, two-tracked station, with two [[side platform]]s that are slightly offset from one another. The standard [[Interborough Rapid Transit Company|IRT]] name tablet [[mosaic]]s are original as well as the fancy ceiling accents and the iron pillars. On the southbound platform is a wooden token booth and ticket chopper, wooden restroom doors on each side. The walls on the platforms are clad in pink stone at the bottom, followed by white tiles, the name of the station in white letters and blue mosaics, and decorated tiles at the top. The top part is decorated with tiles depicting vines or artistic depictions of a [[New Amsterdam]] stapled colonial house with the palisade wall in front of it, which gave today's [[Wall Street (Manhattan)|Wall Street]] its name. The entrances are covered with curved metal roofs painted green. The metal is sculpted with patterns made to resemble wood or leaves. There is a crossunder about midway along the length of the platforms, and a lesser-used one at the north end. ===Exits=== There are three exit areas. On the south end, between Rector Street and Exchange Place, there are two exits to either side of Broadway, with the northbound exits on the east side and the southbound exits on the west side. There are faux kiosks on the southbound side. A complex underground passageway exists outside the [[fare control]] which connects to the [[Broad Street (BMT Nassau Street Line)|Broad Street]] station on the [[BMT Nassau Street Line]], and to the [[Wall Street (IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line)|Wall Street]] station on the Brooklyn Branch of the [[IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line]]. This passageway also leads to the Chase Manhattan Plaza and the old [[Equitable Building (Manhattan)|Equitable Building]]. The stations have a shared exit to the eastern corner of Cedar and Nassau Streets.{{cite NYCS map|Lower Manhattan}} On the north end on the southbound side only, there is an exit under the Trinity Building. It has an opulent gold-colored banner proclaiming "SUBWAY ENTRANCE" atop the entrance, which is half a flight below ground. The exit also has a [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]] restaurant outside fare control.{{cite web | title=TRINITY BUILDING SUBWAY ENTRANCE, Financial District | website=Forgotten New York | date=2015-11-26 | url=http://forgotten-ny.com/2015/11/trinity-building-subway-entrance-financial-district/ | accessdate=2017-01-02}} {{stack|float=left|{{Lower Manhattan transit}}}} {{clear left}} == Renovation == The original white tiles from the early 20th century were walled over with glossy dark blue tiles in the 1970s, with only the name of station allowed to stay. Similar remodeling work was done during that time with [[51st Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|51st Street]] station on the [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]], using beige tiles. In 2006, a project to renovate/restore the station back to its original appearance began. As of May 2006, the blue tiles mentioned above had been removed and remnants of the original white tile-work exposed. The condition of the original tiles were fair to poor to completely missing. All missing tiles were refitted based on original models. {{Clear|left}} == Image gallery == File:Wall Street IRT 008b.JPG|Depiction of the wall of New Amsterdam on a mosaic tile File:Wall Street IRT Lex-Ave Old Ticket Booth.jpg|Old wooden ticket booth File:Wall Street IRT 004.JPG|View of the wall, consisting of pink stone at the bottom, white tiles, the mosaic name of the station and further artful tiles File:Wall Street IRT 007.JPG|Decorated ceiling elements == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * Lee Stokey.
